title: Have engineers always been scientists? - Quora

response.answer_text: The modern 21st century adjectives are slightly different than their historical meanings. Take the Roman aqueducts. Clearly built by Engineers. They are tangible things. However, in order to construct the concrete thing shown, it was not necessary to have had a natural philosopher (the predecessor to the contemporary natural scientist) discover the rules and laws that govern arches, building materials, physics, etc. It was entirely acceptable (the things are still standing today) to have a group of Engineers test and optimize the best ways in which to construct the aqueduct structures—irrespective of the underlying rules of gravity, physics, etc. Yes, they needed to measure things, but modern mechanics didn’t exist. So the principles were not there in any formal sense.  I would say, Engineer and Scientist are not mutually exclusive nouns. A Scientist may find themselves doing some “engineering”, and an Engineer may find themselves taking a step back to study some Science. What would you call yourself, then? I would say it is best to stick to a label that describes the majority of what you’re paid for. If you run HPLC all day to purify things, in an attempt to get the purest compound (while studying how to optimize the HPLC conditions via changing packing material chemistry), then you’re an Engineer. If you run HPLC all day to study the efficacy of elution fractions on inhibiting a sub-set of signal transduction pathways in various cell lines and their mechanisms, you’re probably a Scientist. The term Vocational is relevant here. If your work mainly contains vocational/trade elements, then you’re mainly an Engineer. The term scientific method is somewhat relevant here. Though nowadays it isn’t the rule anymore, in general, if your work requires use of some form of a scientific method, then you are most likely a Scientist. Engineers can get away without rigorous application of a scientific method to carry out their work. The gray areas are that, unlike the Roman aqueducts, Engineering nowadays does utilize a set of Laws/Theories. The latter historically derived from the work of Scientists (physicists mostly). But, many Engineers do modify the Laws/Theories as well. However, they do it to further their engineering principles, not just for the sake of the Scientific Law itself. That brings me to an important point: the end goal. Many Scientists (myself included) can get pretty annoyed over the mentality of an Engineer (a majority of them, at least). I think this is what engenders the sensitivity of someone being called A. or B. Engineers by nature are rather superficial in their treatment of particulars. They love modelling things—regardless if the model captures reality—in an attempt to show something follows a pattern towards an “optimal” set of conditions. Upon retrospect, it isn’t all to uncommon for reproduction of this model to fail. However, under the same exact conditions (of time, weather, Voodoo magic, etc.), the optimized method works very well. Finally, many would say an Engineer is an Applied Scientist. OK. Labels are labels, but, when I find the applied science my colleague did fails to describe the nature of the effect, I largely question what science, exactly, were you applying, dear Engineer?

I disagree with many statements in your description: "Science has officially been around for 500 years or so"  Science has been around for thousands of years, rationalism came a few centuries ago with Rene Descartes. Rationalism was a powerful advancement in the scientific field and led to the progress we all know today. The rough idea is that everything is rational and can be deduced through rationality rejecting the rest. (This led to the major fight in the West between the church and scientists, but this is a digression so let's keep the answer concise.)What you seem to think is science is actually known as Experimental Sciences, say Statistics, Probability Theory etc.. All these appeared a few centuries ago and are actually based on this "trial and error" fashion or empirical observations. Before the rationalism appeared, Science was more abstract, and gave amazing results. For instance, Eratosthenes was able to calculate the circumference of the earth with an amazing accuracy (error of 16.3% or 1.6% depending on the historical data) given the technology. And we can go on with many things discovered before this "500 years". These results were far more abstract and based on theoretical approach not "trial and error". On the other hand, engineering as we know them today appeared during the Renaissance era not "since the beginning of civilization". Before that, it didn't really have scientific basis and was mostly a know-how. Some architects were able to design wonders and some geniuses were able to build them but it was mostly different from science.

(Skip to bottom if you want the TL;DR short version. I would’ve written a shorter response, but I didn’t have time…. >:-) I remember a poster in my grade school library, with great illustrations showing the 10 categories of the Dewey Decimal System - in particular, that the 500s were “Science” and that the 600s were “Technology” - or, actually, I think they may’ve been called “Applied Science”, with the idea being that the 500s were “Pure Science”. The former include things like math, astronomy, biology, chemistry, physics, and geology. The latter include medicine, agriculture, manufacturing, and ‘engineering’ and ‘chemical engineering’. (There is also the 300s category of the social sciences, like economics, political science, psychology, and sociology, but in 6th grade I didn’t care about those. >;-) That distinction has stuck with me for 40 years, and I think is helpful here. Although the line is blurry at best, many scientists are quite obviously not engineers, and many engineers are not at all scientists, at least if we try to draw some distinction. Otherwise, it’s useless to have two different terms. I’d offer at least one crude way to think about it: know, vs. make/do. Scientists attempt to explain and understand things. In fact, the original term during the Enlightenment era was “natural philosophy”, meaning “love/pursuit of knowledge about nature” (nature in the sense of the physical world/universe, not trees and bunnies). They may and often do use engineering in the course of their discovery - building an apparatus or inventing techniques - but those are not the objective. (Think particle accelerators like CERN, or radio telescopes, or 18th c. glassblowing chemical equipment, e.g..)Engineers attempt to create: to design or build or invent something, or to make something happen. (I’d add ….using ‘systems’.) While they may and often do use a discovery process like the scientific method, testing different approaches, they also often do not. An architect engineering a house would be a good example of this - it would be a stretch to call what he’s doing “science”, while it is certainly “engineering”. On the other hand, a chemical engineer, say, may often need to ‘do science’ - research and experimentation - in order to engineer a refinery or fine-chemical production process.Now of course there’s often crossover, where both science and engineering are brought into play, as shown above. It’s more a question of purpose, emphasis, end-goals, than it is discovery vs. creation. And trying to separate the people into two distinct, non-overlapping classes is of course difficult at best and silly/pointless at worst. But to answer the original question, given the above: No. An engineer is not inherently also a scientist, although he/she may also ‘do science’. And vice versa. It’s not so much about the person/title as it is the activity in question.  One last thought, as a comparison: “is a composer considered a musician?”. And my answer is analogous: no, although a composer usually also plays music, in fact usually must just in order to compose. Thinking of the popular music industry: there are bands who write their own music and perform; there are professional songwriters who write the songs that are performed by others - and there are the pop stars who perform songs written by others (not to slam, say, Justin Bieber - I think even he apparently does some of his own songwriting…. >;-) But when someone says “I’m a composer”, they are not saying the same thing as “I’m a musician”. Otherwise, again, we don’t need two terms. (And, oh yeah: “singer-songwriter” is a term of art in that field, which is telling.)

In the broad sense of the term “scientist” - which is simply one who applies the scientific method to the determination of “truth” - yes, engineers are very likely to spend a good deal of time acting as “scientists.” Many people are, whether they are professionally employed in conducting scientific research or not. In the sense of the term “scientist” meaning “one whose profession is the conducting of scientific research, with no specific end product or process intended as the result,” then no, engineers are not scientists, nor vice-versa. The primary distinction is that while both professions very often conduct research using the scientific method, the engineer is applying this method and conducting his or her research with the specific goal of furthering a specific practical design, while the scientist is conducting research simply to gain knowledge about the item or phenomenon being studied. The two fields are very similar, of course, and both scientists and engineers conduct research, publish, and often teach. It’s the focus on the design of a specific product/process vs. the “pure” pursuit of knowledge that is the big difference.

An engineer is not a scientist. An engineer requires scientific knowledge, and in some point in his career may be intensely interested in what some scientist is studying that he might apply in his work, but an engineer uses scientific principles to design and operate equipment, to move and interact materials. An engineer can spend 50 years in that profession and never do anything that advances science. Scientists observe, explain, and quantify natural phenomena. They may demonstrate their understanding of that phenomena, but will not attempt to employ it in any large way. Now you may choose to use the “Uncle Fred” rule and say, “well my Uncle Fred was an electrical engineer and he worked in a laboratory and discovered the principle of intra-granular transconductance. In that case, uncle Fred had the scientist’s hat on. He was doing science, not engineering.

Practicing engineers, that is those who work in industry designing things are generally NOT scientists. This represents the majority of the engineers working today. We use techniques developed through both scientific study done by others as well as those learned by experience to design and test things for use by our society. Academic and research engineers (those employed doing research, either in universities or industrial research centers) ARE scientists. Their focus is not on designing products for use, but on discovering new technologies which, once studied and proved in a research setting can be applied by practicing engineers. Most of this group will hold PhD degrees in engineering. Getting a PhD REQUIRES doing original research, and that research is carried out using scientific techniques.

Engineering is essentially “Applied Science”. At some schools engineering is the faculty of Applied Science. While many in the scientific community consider us engineers to be as a lesser level than us, there would be no point to science if some use were not made of it. Basically scientists make the discoveries that allow engineers to make the things that improve life. We are part of the same team though we may never meet and some science my go unable to be used for hundreds of years before we figure out what to do with it. The scientific community as shown on Big Bang Theory do not consider us scientist as shown by Sheldon’s disdain for Howard’s MIT engineering degree but Howard is the one that went to space. While a TV show is not real life they are illustrating the opinion of many. But we engineers knew what we were getting into and if the opinion of some is that we are not scientists then that is OK. As it cannot be expressed mathematically, whether we are scientists or not is just an opinion. My point is that there is no firm answer.

Depends. Many are. There's a big overlap between applied scientists and engineers and lots of engineers do research. Now, time to infuriate the engineers. Claiming that being an engineer qualifies you as a scientist is outright misrepresentation of credentials. I have fair overlap in training with engineers and I would NEVER call myself an engineer. For fifty years, I've been observing crank science, and whenever a “scientist" supports crank science, whether Velikovsky, creationism, opposition to continental drift, 9/11 conspiracies, moon landing hoaxes, the odds are very high the person is an engineer or applied scientist. Then there was the guy who claimed his expertise in vapor depositing thin films somehow related to climate change. And the guy who told me his engineering education qualified him to opine on the Twin Towers. Turns out he was an ARCHITECT whose expertise was renovating one and two story buildings. Oh well, only 108 short. So if you're an engineer, and I just made you mad, GOOD. Start speaking out.

Have engineers always been scientists? Engineers predate Scientists by over 1000 years! Today’s engineers can spend years or decades or entire careers without applying the scientific method But most engineers will end up applying the scientific method - or the engineering version of it - from time to time Scientific method Get lots of information together, Formulate Hypothesis, Test Hypothesis Publish results Engineering method Get lots of information together, Formulate Hypothesis, Test Hypothesis USE results

As far as I know, there's no organization protecting the title "scientist" (in the countries I lived and worked in at least: France, China, Singapore, Canada). So there is no official definition of scientist. The title "engineer" is protected in some places: France, Canada and USA at least, but most likely many more. Now, for an unofficial definition, I would say a scientist is a generic word for someone who uses a scientific process to understand and predict causes and effects. Engineers should be a subfamily of scientists using their knowledge and science to build things and solve practical issues. So an engineer is a special class of scientist.

There is some overlap between science and engineering. If you look in any university department you will see professors doing fundamental research in areas of interest to engineering. There is research in combustion phenomenon, fluid mechanics, thermal radiation, systems modeling, algorithms, material science, to name a few areas. Generally these engineer/scientists will have PhD’s. Your average engineer (with or without a PhD) can and often does work alongside scientists on scientific projects. Many engineers are involved with the design and construction of particle accelerators, telescopes, and space missions.

Being a scientist is largely a state of mind and opportunity, so some engineers are scientists— but likely no more so than medical doctors; most people simply do not have the requisite mindset or motivation.

In many ways, engineers are simply applied scientists.Scientist go out and discover interesting new phenomena.Engineers scan their publications, and occasionally latch on to one of them, with a view to harnessing the new phenomenon as a means of getting are particular job done. (And getting a particular job done then usually implies that there is a commercial interest in doing it).

Two different sets of employment. Not all engineers are scientists, and not all scientists are also engineers. You could similarly ask, “are engineers mathematicians?” while scientists and engineers use some of the same tools and formulas, each is specialized to their field. I do believe science is more knowledge and discovery-oriented, while engineering is slanted to the applications of the principles in design.

No. If we go by the definition. Scientists do research work. They work on innovation and invent new things. And engineers merely apply on the science they've learnt. Although, It Doesn't mean that engineers cannot invent.
Engineers are about Applied Science - they know a great deal of science but do not practice science.
NopAn engineer doesn't​ do any research work.He works by studying what's already present.And Scientists researches something completely new and unique.
